questions.text: In breast cancer, chest wall involvement means involvement of all of the below mentioned structures except
questions.solution:
Chest wall involvement in Breast CA does not involve Pectoralis major.

Chest wall involvement in case of breast carcinoma means involvement of

  • Ribs
  • Intercostal muscles
  • Serratus anterior  

Stage 4a indicates chest wall involvement.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with the following finding. Which of the following is not true about her condition?

choices.text: Occurs due to excess collagen deposition
It grows beyond primary wound margin

questions.solution:
The above image shows a keloid. It is not a precancerous condition.

Keloid scars are associated with elevated levels of growth factors. A keloid scar is defined as excessive scar tissue that extends beyond the boundaries of the original incision or wound. Its etiology is unknown but is associated with elevated levels of growth factor, deeply pigmented skin, and inherited tendencies and certain areas of the body (triangle whose points are the xiphisternum and each shoulder tip).

Keloid scars do not improve spontaneously with time and excision of the keloid scar has a high rate of recurrence.

Treatment:

  • Pressure- local moulds or elastic garments
  • Silicone gel sheeting
  • Intralesional triamcinolone injection
  • Excision and steroid injections
  • Excision and postoperative radiation (external beam or brachytherapy)
  • Intralesional excision
  • Laser to reduce redness
  • Vitamin E and palm oil massage

Difference between keloid and hypertrophic scar:

Features Hypertrophic scar Keloid
Genetic predisposition Not familial May be familial - Autosomal dominant with incomplete penetration
Age Children Adolescents. Middle age
Sex Equal in both More common in females
Race No predilection African American, Asian, Hispanic
Site Anywhere (more common on flexor surfaces) Neck, chest, ear lobes, shoulders, upper back
Timings 4–6 weeks postinjury Symptom-free interval; may appear years after injury
Symptoms Raised, some pruritus respects wound confines Pain, pruritus, hyperesthesia, growth beyond wound margins
Regression Frequent spontaneous No
Contracture Frequent Rare
Histology Parallel orientation of collagen fibers Hypocellular, thick, wavy collagen fibers in random orientation

questions.text: All of the given parameters are included in the Revised Trauma Score (RTS) system except:
questions.solution:
Heart rate is not a parameter included in the Revised Trauma Score (RTS) system.

RTS is a scoring system that assesses the overall condition of the injured patient by using a combination of the Glasgow Coma Scale, systolic blood pressure, and respiratory rate. The patient is triaged using its scoring system of 0 to 12. A higher score is related to a higher probability of survival.

Related Pearl: Trauma Scoring Systems

Revised Trauma Score  - Total score 0-12 :

  • Glasgow coma scale
  • Respiratory rate
  • Systolic BP

Glasgow coma scale  - Total score 3-15 :

  • Eye-opening
  • Verbal response
  • Motor response

Abbreviated Injury Scale: AIS severity code – 1(minimal severity) to 6 (presumably fatal)

Injury Severity Score – Total score 1 to 75. Calculated summing the squares of the AIS severity codes for the three most severely injured body regions

Score Severity of injury
3-8 Minor
9-16 Moderate
16-24 Serious
>25 Severe/ Critical

  

Mangled Extremity Severity score: Mnemonic - ELiSA

  • Energy that caused the injury, skeletal and soft tissue injury
  • Limb ischemia
  • Shock
  • Patient’s age

TRISS (Trauma and Injury Severity Score) : Mnemonic - IRMA

  • Injury Severity Score
  • Revised Trauma Score
  • Mechanism of Injury (blunt/penetrating)
  • Age

questions.text: Amyloid stroma is characteristically seen in which Thyroid Carcinoma
questions.solution:
Medullary thyroid carcinoma shows cells resembling those in carcinoid tumors with the characteristic amyloid stroma in a histological section.

Option A:

Papillary carcinoma thyroid shows

  • Papillary projections
  • Orphan-Annie eyed nuclei (pale empty nuclei)
  • Psammoma bodies (microscopic calcified deposits)

Option B:

Follicular carcinoma thyroid shows follicles which might be devoid of colloid sometimes.

Option D:

Hurthle cell variant is a variant of follicular neoplasm in which oxyphil (Hurthle, Askanazy) cells predominate histologically.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic presents with regurgitation and retrosternal pain. Endoscopic biopsy confirms Barretts oesophagus. It is most commonly associated with
questions.solution:
Barrett’s oesophagus is most commonly associated with Adenocarcinoma.

Natural course of Barrett’s oesophagus is:

Treatment:

  • Conservative
  • Anti-reflux surgery – Nissen’s fundoplication

questions.text: The most common functional pancreatic tumour in MEN 1:
questions.solution:
The most common functional tumour in MEN 1 is Gastrinoma.

MEN 1 includes

  • Primary hyperparathyroidism (90%)
  • Pituitary tumors (10-20%)
  • Enteropancreatic tumors (60-70%)
    • Most common enteropancreatic tumor is Gastrinoma followed by Insulinoma.
    • Other tumors that are seen are VIPoma, Glucagonoma

questions.text: Investigation of choice for solitary rectal ulcer
questions.solution: Colonoscopy with biopsy is the investigation of choice for diagnostic evaluation in Solitary rectal ulcer.

questions.text: TUR syndrome is due to
questions.solution:
TUR syndrome occurs as a complication of TURP procedure and is due to Water intoxication.

Prolonged use of hypotonic irrigation fluid, results in fluid overload, and dilutional hyponatremia causing water intoxication also known as transurethral resection(TUR) syndrome. 

Absorption of water into the circulation at the time of transurethral urethral resection can lead to :

  • Hyponatremia, which may manifest as confusion, nausea, and vomiting
  • Congestive cardiac failure
  • Hemolysis 
  • Hypertension,
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Bradycardia.

Management:

  • Treatment consists of fluid restriction.

questions.text: A 35-year-old housewife presents with low-voltage electric burns injury. Such domestic low voltage electrical injury can cause all of the following except
questions.solution:
Electric injury -

The current enters at one point and then leaves the body at an exit point, usually to the earth or the neutral conductor of the electricity supply.  

It tends to take the shortest route between entry and best exit, irrespective of the varying conductivity of different internal tissues.

When a hand is brought into contact with a live conductor, and the body is earthed either through the feet or the opposite hand, the most common passage of current is across the heart.

It has been claimed that the most dangerous current path is contacted with the right hand and exit through the left foot, as this causes the maximum (up to 8.5 percent) of the total body current to flow through the heart when compared with head to feet (up to 5.9 percent), left hand to feet (up to 5.1 percent), hand to hand (up to 4.4 percent) or foot to foot (up to 0.4 percent)

Direct current (d.c.) is less dangerous than alternating current (a.c.).

Most deaths from electricity are from cardiac arrhythmias, usually, ventricular fibrillation ending in cardiac arrest.

It is commonly said that tolerance can be gained to electric shock and that professional electricians often work on live 240 V conductors with impunity.

In the case of the person touching a 240-volt conductor while standing on a carpeted wooden floor upstairs, the poor earth will allow only a small current to flow and all that may be suffered is a painful muscular spasm.

The person touching the neutral and live wires with the same finger a few centimeters apart may suffer from a severe local burn but no danger to life.

Various skin lesions in electrical injury:

  • When the skin has been in firm contact with an electrical conductor, this may split the layers of the epidermis or the epidermal-dermal junction and produce a raised blister called Joule burns.
  • In high-voltage burns, such as those sustained from high-tension grid transmission cables, where the voltage is in the multi-kilovolt range, sparking may occur over many centimeters. This can cause multiple spark lesions giving rise to a ‘crocodile-skin’ effect.
  • The heat generated by the current may melt the calcium phosphate, which is radiologically seen as typical round dense foci called as 'bone pearls' or 'wax drippings'.

  • When the contact with the electrocuting surface is not firm, the skin lesion that develops is called a spark lesion. When the contact is less firm, an air gap (albeit narrow) exists between skin and conductor the current jumps the gap as a spark. This causes the outer skin keratin to melt over a small area. On cooling, the keratin fuses into a hard brownish nodule, usually raised above the surrounding surface.

questions.text: Rectal carcinoma is staged by:
questions.solution:
Modified Duke's staging is used in rectal carcinoma.

TNM stage Modified Dukes Stage Description
T1N0M0 A Limited to submucosa
T2N0M B1 Limited to muscularis propia
T3N0M0 B2 Transmural extension
T2N1M0 C1 T2, enlarged mesenteric nodes
T3N1M0 C2 T2, enlarged mesenteric nodes
T4 C2 T3, enlarged mesenteric nodes
Any T,M1 D Distant metastases present
  • Option B : Bloom Richardson grading  - Carcinoma breast.
  • Option C : Nevine staging - For staging in cases of carcinoma of Gallbladder.
  • Option D : Robson’s staging - For staging in cases of Renal Cell Carcinoma.

questions.text: Most common post operative complication of Appendicectomy
questions.solution:
Wound infection is the most common post operative complication of appendicectomy.

  • It occurs in 5–10 per cent of all patients.
  • Presents with:
    • Pain
    • Erythema of the wound on the 4th or 5th postoperative day,
  • Treatment:
    • Wound drainage and Antibiotics

The next most common complication is: Intra abdominal abscess.

questions.text: Lymphatics from superolateral quadrant of breast drain into all of the following group of lymph nodes except:
questions.solution:
Lymphatics from superolateral quadrant of breast do not drain into parasternal nodes.

Lymphatics from superolateral quadrant of breast drains into Axillary group of lymph nodes which includes

  • Lateral
  • Anterior
  • Posterior
  • Central
  • Apical group of lymph nodes

Lymphatic drainage:

The lymphatics of the breast drain predominantly into the axillary and internal mammary lymph nodes.

Internal mammary nodes drain posterior one third of breast.

The Axillary nodes receive 85 per cent of the drainage:

  • Lateral - along the axillary vein-drains most of upper limb
  • Anterior - along the lateral thoracic vessels - drains most of breast (1st relay station for lymph)
  • Posterior - along the subscapular vessels.
  • Central - embedded in fat in the centre of the axilla.
  • Apical - It receives the efferents from all the other groups and drains in to subclavian lymphatic trunk.
  • Interpectoral (rotters node) a few nodes lying between the pectoralis major and minor muscles.

Related Pearl: Breast Lump Evaluation

questions.text: Most common neoplasm of appendix:
questions.solution:
Carcinoid tumors are the most common primary tumor identified in the appendix.

  • These neoplasms arise from neuroendocrine cells from within the appendix
  • These are typically small, well-circumscribed lesions that are located within the more distal aspect of the appendix.

Treatment:

  • Based on size:
    • Carcinoids < 1 cm -  Appendicectomy.
    • Carcinoids > 2 cm - Right hemicolectomy with regional lymphadenectomy.

questions.text: A young man was brought unconscious to casualty following a road traffic accident. CT scan appeared normal. MRI showed multiple small hemorrhages in the corpus callosum and the dorsolateral midbrain with no midline shift. The most probable cause is -
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a high-impact injury (road traffic accident) with a normal CT scan and microhemorrhages on MRI points toward the diagnosis of Diffuse Axonal Injury (DAI).

Diffuse axonal injury (white matter shearing) is the result of shearing forces, typically from a rotational acceleration of the brain within the rigid cranium. This causes damage to microvasculature and also leads to disruption of axons in the subcortical parasagittal white matter, cerebellum, fornix, and internal and external capsule. Most commonly it occurs in automobile accidents. Patients are usually unconscious from the moment of impact and remain the same until death.

Diffuse axonal injury is characterized by multiple focal lesions with a characteristic distribution:

  • CT may be normal.
  • MRI is the modality of choice for assessing suspected diffuse axonal injury even in patients with entirely normal CT of the brain.
  • MRI, especially SWI (susceptibility-weighted imaging) demonstrates small regions of susceptibility artefact or hemorrhage.

The image below shows an SWI in DAI.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

Related Pearl: Diffuse Axonal Injury

The mechanism of diffuse axonal injury (DAI) is primarily a non-impact rotational acceleration-deceleration injury. This leads to the deformation of the axons by stretching them.

Pathology of DAI:

  • Changes in permeability of the axolemma
  • Axonal swelling
  • Intracellular calcium accumulation
  • Proteolysis
  • The collapse of the cytoskeleton
  • 'Retraction balls or globes' - bulbous and clubbed axons. Seen earliest at 12-18 hours. The number of retraction balls begins to decrease after 2-3 weeks after injury and a cluster of microglial cells appears followed by astrocytosis and demyelination.
  • Immuno-histochemistry shows beta-amyloid precursor protein - the most reliable indicator of axon damage. Seen earliest at 2-3 hours. 

Image shows scattered axonal retraction balls stained with Congo Red:

questions.text: Barium enema of a 60 year old patient with intestinal obstruction shows the following picture. What is the  probable diagnosis :
questions.solution:
The given image depicts the 'Apple core appearance' in barium enema which is characteristic of Carcinoma colon. 

Radiographic appearances reflect macroscopic appearance, with lesions seen as filling defects.

Option D: Characteristic radiologic findings in Crohn's colitis:

  • Skip lesions
  • Contour defects
  • Longitudinal and transverse ulcers
  • A cobblestone-like mucosal pattern
  • Strictures
  • Thickening of the haustral margin
  • Irregular nodular defects

questions.text: In case of head injury CT brain is indicated in all except:
questions.solution:
More than one episode of vomiting is an indication for CT scan in head injury.

Related Pearl: NICE Guidelines for CT in Head Injury

National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) Guidelines for Computed Tomography (CT) in Head Injury

Indications for CT imaging within 1 hour of the following risk factors being identified:

  • Glasgow Coma Score (GCS) <12 on initial assessment
  • GCS <15 at 2 hours after injury on assessment in an emergency department
  • Focal neurological deficit
  • Suspected open, depressed, or basal skull fracture
  • More than one episode of vomiting
  • Post-traumatic seizure

Indications for CT imaging within 8 hours:

  • Age >65 years
  • Bleeding or clotting disorders
  • Dangerous mechanism of injury (e.g., fall from a height of >1 meter/5 stairs, road traffic accident)
  • Retrograde amnesia >30 minutes

questions.text: You are a resident doctor in the General Surgery Department of a Hospital. You have been given the task of arranging the following surgeries to be posted for tomorrow’s Operation Theatre. Which of the following surgeries will you post first in the OT list
questions.solution:
Right hemithyroidectomy is a Clean Procedure and hence shall occupy the first position in the given list of surgeries.

Cleaner surgeries are posted first in the OT list.

Clean Procedures

  • CABG , Thyroid Sx, Breast Sx ( except abscess), Knee replacement

Clean contaminated 

  • Gastrointestinal or genitourinary system without inflammation 
  • Eg: Elective appendicectomy, Elective cholecystectomy

Contaminated procedures 

  • GI / GU system with Non purulent inflammation  
  • Eg Same as above in an emergency setting

Dirty wounds 

  • Pus present , Peritonitis , Traumatic wound not managed for > 6 hrs

questions.text: Length of a flexible sigmoidoscope is :
questions.solution:
Flexible sigmoidoscope is 60 cm in length and can be used to visualize rectum and sigmoid colon.

Flexible sigmoidoscopy:

A procedure wherein a sigmoidoscope is inserted through the anus, the distal colonic mucosa (up to 60 cm from the anal verge) is examined, and any diagnostic or therapeutic maneuvers performed, as needed.    

Scope Length (cm)
Proctoscope 10-12 
Rigid Sigmoidoscope 25 
Flexible sigmoidoscope 60 
Colonoscope 160

questions.text: According to Nyhus Classification femoral hernia is:
questions.solution:
Femoral hernia in Nyhus classification is Type III c.

Nyhus Classification of Groin Hernia

 

  • Type I: Indirect inguinal hernia with internal inguinal ring normal.
  • Type II: Indirect inguinal hernia with internal inguinal ring dilated by posterior wall intact, inferior epigastric vessels not displaced.
  • Type III: Posterior wall defect. 
  • IIIA: Direct inguinal hernia. 
  • IIIB: Indirect inguinal hernia with internal inguinal ring dilated, medially encroaching on or destroying the tranversalis facia of hesselbach's traingle.
  • IIIC: Femoral hernia
  • Type IV: Recurrent hernia
    • A: Direct 
    • B: Indirect
    • C: Femoral
    • D: Combined

questions.text: Which part of colon is most prone for ischemic gangrene:
questions.solution: Splenic flexure is a watershed area between superior and inferior mesenteric artery supply and thus prone for ischemia.

questions.text: All of the following statements about pleomorphic adenoma are true except

choices.text: Parotid gland is the most commonly affected gland
It is also known as mixed tumor

questions.solution:
Malignant change occurs in 3-5% of cases of pleomorphic adenoma and is referred to as carcinoma ex pleomorphic adenoma.

Symptoms suggestive of malignant transformation:

  • Rapid growth
  • Pain
  • Paraesthesias
  • Enlarged cervical lymph nodes
  • Restriction of jaw movements
  • Facial weakness
  • Skin invasion
  • Fixation of mastoid tip.

Pleomorphic adenoma:

  • Most common benign salivary gland tumor.
  • Most commonly affected gland is parotid gland. Superficial lobe is most commonly affected.
  • Also called mixed tumor since it has both epithelial and mesenchymal components.

Clinical features:

  • Most commonly affects females around 40 years of age.
  • Most common presenting feature – painless swelling below, in front and behind the ear.
  • Involvement of deep lobe leads to dumbbell tumor – swelling in both neck and oral cavity.

Diagnosis:

  • FNAC – investigation of choice. 
  • Open biopsy contraindicated due to chances of injury to facial nerve.

Treatment:

  • Surgery is the mainstay of treatment - Superficial parotidectomy (Patey's operation).

questions.text: The lymph nodes marked  "X" in the below image denote
questions.solution:
The lymph nodes marked "X" in the given diagram are Paracolic lymph nodes.

  • Paracolic lymph nodes are located along the marginal artery.
  • Epicolic lymph nodes are located along the bowel wall.
  • Intermediate nodes along the larger blood vessels.

questions.text: The gross appearance of a resected specimen from a patient who presented with testicular swelling is shown below. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: Histopathology is likely to reveal cells showing 'fried-egg' appearance
Postoperative surveillance using tumour markers is advised

questions.solution:
The above image shows a testicular mass that is homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface, devoid of haemorrhage or necrosis. This is suggestive of seminoma. 

Seminoma is the most common type of germ cell tumour and it commonly in patients with a history of cryptorchidism. It is the testicular equivalent of an ovarian dysgerminoma. Immunohistochemistry is positive for KIT, OCT3/4, and placental alkaline phosphatase (PLAP). 

Clinical features of testicular carcinoma:

  • Painless testicular lump is the most common presenting feature.
  • Epididymo-orchitis.
  • Severe pain and acute enlargement of the testis because of haemorrhage into the tumour.
  • Intra-abdominal spread may cause abdominal or lumbar pain.
  • Lung metastases are usually silent but they can cause chest pain, dyspnoea and haemoptysis in the later stages of the disease.

Sonography is mandatorily done in all suspected cases. Tumour markers which may be elevated in up to 50% of cases, should be investigated prior to orchiectomy. This serves as useful in follow-up after surgery.

An orchidectomy through an inguinal incision is performed as a definitive treatment. Surveillance using CT imaging and tumour markers to look for metastasis or relapse is done. It is radiosensitive and responds to radiotherapy.

The gross appearance of the testis in seminoma is characterized by a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface, devoid of haemorrhage or necrosis.

The histological examination shows sheets of uniform cells with clear or water-appearing cytoplasm with varying amounts of glycogen. There is a large central nucleus, with one or two prominent nucleoli, contributing to the 'fried-egg appearance'. These sheets of cells are poorly demarcated into lobules by delicate fibrous septa, containing lymphocytic infiltrate. 

Related Pearl: Most common testicular tumors

Pre-pubertal age group Yolk sac tumor
15–34 years Germ-cell tumors
Adults Seminomatous and non-seminomatous
Elderly age group Lymphoma
Germ-cell testicular tumor Seminoma
Bilateral testicular tumor Lymphoma

 

Related Pearl: Seminomatous germ-cell tumors (GCTs) vs Non-seminomatous GCT

Features Seminoma Non- seminomatous GCT
Age 2nd or 3rd decade (Never seen in prepubertal children) Occur at any age
Presentation Localized to the testis for a long time Aggressive tumors; present at an advanced clinical stage
Spread Lymphatic Hematogenous
Macroscopy Homogenous Variegated
Cell type Composed of primordial germ cells Composed of undifferentiated cells
Tumor marker Placental alkaline phosphatase AFP, HCG
Radio-therapy Radiosensitive Radioresistant
Prognosis Better Poor

AFP: Alpha-fetoprotein 

HCG: Human Chorionic Gonadotropin

Related Pearl: WHO 2016 classification of testicular tumors

I. Germ-cell tumors (GCTs) derived from germ-cell neoplasia in situ

  • Germ-cell neoplasia in situ
  • Seminoma
  • Non-seminomatous GCTs
    • Embryonal carcinoma
    • Yolk sac tumor, postpubertal-type
    • Choriocarcinoma
    • Teratoma, post-pubertal type
  • Mixed germ-cell tumors

II. Germ-cell tumors unrelated to germ-cell neoplasia in situ

  • Spermatocytic tumour
  • Teratoma, prepubertal type
  • Yolk sac tumor, prepubertal type
  • Mixed

III. Sex cord stromal tumors

  • Leydig cell tumor
  • Sertoli cell tumor
  • Granulosa cell tumor
  • Fibroma–thecoma

IV. Tumor containing both germ-cell and sex cord-stromal elements

  • Gonadoblastoma

V. Hematolymphoid tumors

questions.text: False statement regarding diverticulosis is

choices.text: Most colonic diverticula are false diverticula
Most persons with diverticular disease remain asymptomatic throughout their lives
Low fiber diet is a risk factor

questions.solution:
Diverticulosis is commoner in older age group. 

  • The formation of diverticula is related to aging.    
  • Diverticula are rare in individuals < 30 years, but common in the age 80 yrs (66 %).

 Diverticulosis   

  • It is a condition that develops when pouches form in the wall of the colon. They are herniations of mucosa or bowel wall through the point of entry of blood vessels.
  • A True diverticulum is composed of all layers of the intestinal wall,
  • A False diverticulum, or pseudodiverticulum, lacks a portion of the normal bowelwall. False diverticula are more common. They are usually asymptomatic.
  • Low fiber diet is a risk factor for diverticulosis formation.

questions.text: Commonest manifestation of Wilm’s tumor is
questions.solution:
Abdominal lump is the most common manifestation of Wilm’s tumor.

Other presenting symptoms include:

  • Abdominal pain 
  • Hematuria, which may signify tumor invasion into the collecting system or ureter 
  • Hypertension (25%)

questions.text: The most common fistula seen in complicated diverticulitis:
questions.solution:
Colovesical fistulas are the most common fistula seen in complicated Diverticulitis.

Inflammation in diverticulitis cause local attachments leading to fistula most commonly in bladder.

Other sites of fistula formation are:

  • Vagina
  • Skin
  • Small intestine

Diverticulitis is a more common cause of a fistula between the colon and bladder than Crohn’s disease or cancer.

Sigmoid-vesicular fistulas are more common in men than in women because the uterus prevents the sigmoid from adhering to the bladder.

questions.text: Below knee perforator is also known as
questions.solution:
Below knee perforator is also known as Boyd perforator.

Named perforators:

  • Mid-thigh perforators - Hunterian perforator
  • Above knee - Dodd perforator
  • Below knee - Boyd perforator
  • Lower leg (medial calf) - Cockett I, II, III perforators
  • Ankle perforators - May or Kuster

questions.text: Deep inguinal ring is a defect in
questions.solution:
• Deep inguinal ring is a defect in fascia transversalis.
  • This ring lies midway between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic tubercle, approximately 2.5 cm above the inguinal ligament.
  • It lies lateral to inferior epigastric vessels.

questions.text: Investigation of choice in Acute Colonic Diverticulitis is
questions.solution:
CT scan is the preferred investigation for evaluation of Acute diverticulitis as information about the pathological changes outside the colon can also be obtained.

Diverticula are identified on CT scans as outpouchings of the colonic wall.

Other findings on CECT are:

  • Linear stranding in the fat of the root of the sigmoid mesentery. 
  • Small extraluminal collections of fluid or air.
  • Attenuation of the fat along with fistulas or large abscesses.
  • Enhancement of the colonic wall.

Option C: Ultrasonography may not be helpful in excluding diverticulosis or diverticulitis because of interference due to bowel gas.

Option D: Colonoscopy in the setting of acute colonic diverticulitis may result in perforation.

questions.text: Hernia containing Meckel’s diverticulum is
questions.solution:
Littre’s hernia is protrusion of Meckel’s diverticulum through an abdominal opening.

Option A:

Richter’s hernia is a type of hernia where sac contains only a portion of circumference of the bowel.

Option C:

Maydl hernias are defined as the presence of two small bowel loops within a single hernial sac, that is, there are two efferent and two afferent loops of bowel, forming a "W" shape.

Option D:

Pantaloon hernia is presence of both direct and indirect hernia on same side simultaneously in a patient.

questions.text: False statement regarding inflammatory bowel disease

choices.text: Smoking is protective in Crohn’s disease
Toxic megacolon is seen in Ulcerative colitis
Skip lesion are seen in Crohn’s disease
Backwash ileitis is seen in Ulcerative colitis

questions.solution:
Smoking is protective in Ulcerative colitis while it is an etiology for Crohn’s disease.

  • Smoking appears to confer a protective effect against the development of ulcerative colitis, as well as providing a therapeutic influence. 
  • This is in contrast to Crohn’s disease, which is more common in smokers and appears to be aggravated by the habit.
  • Backwash ileitis and Toxic megacolon are features of Ulcerative colitis.
  • Skip lesions and Transmural involvement are features of Crohns disease. 

Differentiating features of Crohns disease and ulcerative colitis:

  Crohns disease Ulcerative colitis
Site of origin Terminal ileum Rectum
Pattern of progression Skip lesions/irregular Proximally contiguous
Thickness of inflammation Transmural Submucosa or mucosa
Symptoms Crampy abdominal pain Bloody diarhhea
Complications Fistulas, abscess, obstruction Haemorrhage, toxic megacolon
Radiographic findings String sign on barium X-ray Lead pipe colon on Barium X-ray
Risk of colon cancer Slight increase Marked increase
Surgery For complications such as stricture Curative

questions.text: A patient presented with chest pain radiating to jaw and dysphagia. Motility disorder of esophagus is suspected and manometry is done which shows simultaneous multi-peaked contractions of high amplitude (>120 mm Hg). Probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with chest pain radiating to jaw and dysphagia with manometry showing simultaneous multi-peaked contractions of high amplitude (>120 mm Hg) is characteristic of Diffuse Esophageal Spasm.

Diffuse Esophageal Spasm:

  • DES is a condition in which there are incoordinate contractions of the Oesophagus, causing dysphagia and/or chest pain. 
  • The abnormal contractions are more common in the distal two-thirds of the esophageal body.
  • There is marked hypertrophy of the circular muscle.
  • The classic manometry findings in DES are simultaneous multi-peaked contractions of high amplitude (>120 mm Hg) or long duration (>2.5 seconds).
  • Barium meal shows corkscrew esophagus or pseudo diverticulosis.
  • Peristalsis is normal.
  • Treatment 
    • Calcium channel antagonists, vasodilators and endoscopic dilatation have only transient effects.
    • Surgical treatment includes extended oesophagealmyotomy up to the aortic arch may be required.
    • Surgical treatment of diffuse spasm is more successful in improving dysphagia than chest pain.

Manometric Findings in:

Nutcracker Esophagus:

  • Peristaltic esophageal contractions 2 standard deviations above normal.
  • Amplitude > 180 mmHg and duration > 6 seconds.

Hypertensive Lower Esophageal Sphincter:

  • Elevated LES presure> 26mmHg and normal relaxation of LES.
  • Esophageal body may be hyper-peristaltic or normal.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with bleeding per rectum. On proctoscopy and biopsy, he is diagnosed with anal canal carcinoma. What is the best mode of treatment?

choices.text: Cisplatin based chemotherapy followed by radiotherapy
Radiotherapy followed by Mitomycin C based chemotherapy

questions.solution:
The best mode for treatment of a case of anal carcinoma is cisplatin-based chemotherapy followed by radiotherapy.

Chemoradiotherapy (Nigro regimen) is the primary treatment of anal carcinoma. Chemotherapy usually includes a combination of 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) with mitomycin C or Cisplatin. Chemotherapy is followed by radiotherapy. Radical surgical excision in the form of abdominoperineal resection (APR) is required if any residual tumor is left behind. Surgery may also be required to resolve incontinence or fistulas after tumor resolution and in recurrent disease. 

The most common type of anal canal carcinoma is SCC >BCC >melanoma. The usual symptom is pain and bleeding per rectum. The most common site of metastasis is the lungs. The most common site of nodal metastasis is inguinal lymph nodes.  

Risk factors for carcinoma anal canal:

  • HPV infection (16, 18, 31, 33)
  • HIV or immunosuppression
  •  Smoking
  • Anal receptive intercourse
  • Sexual promiscuity
  • Chronic inflammation
  • Anal intraepithelial neoplasia
  • History of vulvar or cervical cancer

Additional symptoms of incontinence, change in bowel habits, pelvic pain, and rectovaginal or rectovesical fistulas suggest advanced malignancy with infiltration into the sphincters or penetration into the rectal wall. 

Proctoscopy with biopsy is the investigation of choice for diagnosis of CA anal canal. CT abdomen & pelvis are mandatory because all of the draining lymph nodes are not palpable. CT scan is done to evaluate distant metastasis.

Related Pearl: Chemotherapy for GI Tumours

GI malignancy

Chemotherapy

Esophageal carcinoma

ECF (Epirubicin + Cisplatin + 5-FU)

Gastric carcinoma

ECF (Epirubicin + Cisplatin + 5-FU)

Small intestine adenocarcinoma

5-FU

Colorectal carcinoma

FOLFOX-IV (5-FU + Leucovorin + Oxaliplatin)

Carcinoma of the anal canal

Nigro Regimen: Chemoradiation (5-FU + Mitomycin C) + Radiation

questions.text: Most common type of malignant melanoma is
questions.solution:
Superficial spreading melanoma is the most common type (70 per cent) of malignant melanoma.

Types of malignant melanoma:

  • Superficial spreading - Most common
  • Nodular - 15%
  • Lentigo maligna melanoma - 5 -10%
  • Acral - 2 to 8%
  • Desmoplastic - Rare
  • Amelanotic melanoma - Rare

Macroscopic features in naevi suggestive of malignant melanoma: 

  • Change in size – any adult naevus >6 mm is suspect and >10 mm is more likely to be malignant.
  • Shape
  • Colour
  • Thickness (elevation/nodularity or ulceration)
  • Satellite lesions (pigment spreading into surrounding area) 
  • Tingling/itching/serosanguinous discharge (usually late signs)

Notable points:

  • Breslow thickness most important prognostic indicator.
  • Sentinel node biopsy useful for lymphatic mapping.

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding a Wolfe graft except:
questions.solution:
Wolfes graft is a type of full-thickness graft. The best cosmetic appearance is seen with a full-thickness graft.

Full-thickness skin grafts include the epidermis and the complete layer of the dermis. They are used for smaller areas of skin replacement where good elastic skin is required.

Full-thickness grafts are associated with,

  • The greatest amount of primary contraction
  • The least amount of secondary contraction
  • The highest durability
  • The best cosmetic appearance

As a result, they are frequently used in reconstructing superficial wounds on the face and the hands.

  Full-thickness skin graft (Wolfe) Split thickness skin graft (Thiersche)
Structure Epidermis + complete dermis ± fat Epidermis + part of dermis
Donor site location Post auricular, supra/infra-clavicular. 
Never axillary		 Thigh > buttocks
Donor site wound Must be sutured Requires only dressing and can be reused
Recipient site Must be well vascularised. Small area May be inadequately vascularized. Larger area (achieved by meshing)
Graft features
Durability High Low
Contracture Primary > secondary High secondary contracture
Uptake Require more care to ensure uptake High-reliability
Cosmetic result Good Poor (abnormal pigmentation)

questions.text: Which of the following is false about achalasia cardia?

choices.text: Manometry is the gold standard test for diagnosis
Pain is the most common symptom

questions.solution:
Dysphagia -  Difficulty to swallow food and not pain is the most common symptom of achalasia cardia.

Achalasia is a primary esophageal motility disorder. It is characterized by the absence of esophageal peristalsis and impaired lower esophageal sphincter (LES) relaxation in response to swallowing. These abnormalities cause a functional obstruction at the gastroesophageal junction. 

Esophageal manometry is the gold standard and it shows:

  • Incomplete LES relaxation in response to swallowing
  • High resting LES pressure
  • Absent esophageal peristalsis

On performing a timed barium study, barium will be retained for more than five minutes. The fluoroscopic examination will reveal a dilated esophagus that tapers to form a 'bird's beak' at the gastroesophageal junction as seen in the image above. 

Endoscopy and biopsy are usually carried out to rule out cancer as it is a premalignant condition. 

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

  • Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.
  • Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • Regurgitation
  • Chest pain
  • Weight loss
  • Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy

questions.text: Critical limb ischemia corresponds to ABPI of
questions.solution:
Critical limb ischemia refers to rest pain that corresponds to ABPI of <0.3.

  • The ankle–brachial pressure index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the arm.
  • The highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial or peroneal artery serves as the numerator.
  • The highest brachial systolic pressure is the denominator.

Interpretation:

  • >1 – Normal
  • <0.9 – Mild Claudication
  • < 0.5 – Severe Claudication
  • <0.3 – Imminent necrosis/ Critical limb ischemia

questions.text: A 25-year-old man met with an accident and sustained a pelvic fracture. He developed haematuria. Retrograde cystourethrogram showed extraperitoneal bladder rupture. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The usual line of management of extraperitoneal bladder rupture is catheter drainage for 10 days.

Bladder injury can be intraperitoneal or extraperitoneal. Extraperitoneal injuries are more common and are usually associated with pelvic fractures. Intraperitoneal injuries are caused by penetrating injuries or rupture at the dome of a full bladder due to a blow or fall. The symptoms of extraperitoneal bladder injury are suprapubic pain with the inability to void.

CT cystography is the ideal investigation for bladder injury. Retrograde cystography confirms the diagnosis. On retrograde cystogram, a dense, flame-shaped pattern of extravasation of contrast in the pelvis is seen in extraperitoneal bladder rupture.

Management of extraperitoneal rupture of the bladder:

Uncomplicated extraperitoneal bladder injury is usually managed with urethral catheter drainage only. Emergency operative management of bladder injury is done in:

  • Intraperitoneal injury from external trauma
  • Penetrating or iatrogenic non-urologic injury
  • Inadequate bladder drainage or clots in urine
  • Bladder neck injury
  • Rectal or vaginal injury
  • Open pelvic fracture
  • Pelvic fracture requiring open reduction and internal fixation
  • Selected stable patients undergoing laparotomy for other reasons 
  • Bone fragments projecting into the bladder

An algorithm for the management of bladder injury is given below:

questions.text: Most common type of carcinoma esophagus seen in achalasia cardia:
questions.solution:
Achalasia is a pre malignant condition and the most common type of carcinoma seen is Squamous cell carcinoma.

  • It is due to long-standing retained undigested fermenting food in the body of the esophagus, causing mucosal irritation.

questions.text: Flap commonly used in breast reconstruction is
questions.solution:
Transverse Rectus Abdominis Myocutaneous (TRAM) flap is the most commonly used flap for Breast reconstruction.

 It consists of a skin paddle based on the underlying rectus abdominis muscle, which is supplied by vessels from the Deep inferior epigastric artery.

Other Flaps :

  • The Latissimus Dorsi myocutaneous flap -  supplied by the thoracodorsal artery with contributions from the posterior intercostal arteries.
  • Ruben's flap
  • Thoracoepigastric flap
  • Lateral thigh flap
  • Gluteal flap

questions.text: Spontaneous perforation of oesophagus occurs in:
questions.solution:
The Lower third of oesophagus is the commonest site for spontaneous perforation.

  • Spontaneous perforation or Boerhaave syndrome occurs when a person vomits against a closed glottis,the pressure in esophagus rise and  bursts at its weakest point in the lower third.
  • It is a serious type of perforation as large amount of food particles released in to mediastinum which cause rapid chemical irritation in the mediastinum and pleura followed by infection if untreated.

questions.text: The proximal extent of a Crawford type III thoracoabdominal aneurysm is
questions.solution:
Crawford Type 3 extends from Lower descending thoracic aorta to the Abdomen.

Crawford classification of thoracoabdominal aneurysm:     

  • Extent I - Left subclavian artery to the suprarenal abdominal aorta.
  • Extent II (most extensive type) - Left subclavian artery to the infrarenal abdominal aorta, and they often reach the aortic bifurcation.
  • Extent III - Lower descending thoracic aorta (below the sixth rib) to the abdomen.
  • Extent IV - Begins at the diaphragmatic hiatus and often involve the entire abdominal aorta.

questions.text: Perforation of oesophagus is managed surgically in all cases except:
questions.solution:
Instrumental perforations in the cervical oesophagus are usually small and can nearly always are managed conservatively.

Indications for surgical exploration in Esophageal perforation-

  • Large septic load
  • Septic shock
  • Pleura breached
  • Boerhaave’s syndrome
  • Perforation of abdominal esophagus

Indications for considering non operative management in Esophageal perforation-

  • Small septic load
  • Minimal cardiovascular upset
  • Confined to mediastinum
  • By flexible endoscope
  • Cervical esophagus

questions.text: White leg is due to
questions.solution:
White leg also known as phlegmasia alba dolens and is due to Deep vein thrombosis.

  • In this condition the affected extremity is extremely painful and edematous and pale.   
  • It occurs secondary to arterial insufficiency from dramatically elevated below knee compartment pressures.
  • It can be complicated by venous gangrene requiring amputation.

questions.text: Partial posterior fundoplication for GERD is called:
questions.solution:
Partial posterior fundoplication is Toupet’s fundoplication.

 

             Fundoplication Name of the procedure
Total fundoplication Nissen 
Partial posterior fundoplication Toupet 
Partial anterior fundoplication  Dor
Anterolateral fundoplication  Watson

questions.text: Gold standard test for diagnosis of GERD:
questions.solution:
24-hour pH recording is the ‘gold standard’ for diagnosis of GERD.

  • Transient lower esophageal sphincter relaxations are the most important manometric findings in GERD.

24 hour pH recording in GERD:

  • In the proximal esophagus (15 cm above the LES), acid exposure normally occurs less than 1% of the time.
  • In the distal esophagus (5 cm above the LES), it normally occurs less than 4% of the time.

De Meester score

  • An overall score is obtained with the use of a formula that assigns a weight to each item according to its capacity to cause esophageal injury.
  • A value greater than 14.7 indicates reflux.

questions.text: Hereditary Pancreatitis is caused due mutation of:
questions.solution:
PRSS1 and SPINK1 mutations can lead to hereditary pancreatitis.

PRSS1:

  • Mutations in this gene cause premature activation of trypsinogen to trypsin and cause abnormalities of ductal secretion, both of which promote acute pancreatitis.

SPINK1:

  • Mutations in the protein, which blocks the active binding site of trypsin also leads to hereditary pancreatitis.

questions.text: A young man is incidentally found to have a pseudocyst of the pancreas on abdominal ultrasound. Past history is notable for one episode of acute pancreatitis. An aspirate from the cyst is likely to show:

choices.text: Low amylase levels and high carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels
Low amylase levels and low carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels
High amylase levels and high carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels
High amylase levels and low carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels

questions.solution:
An aspirate from a pancreatic pseudocyst is likely to show high amylase levels and low carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels. It is also associated with the absence of mucin.

Pancreatic pseudocysts are non-necrotic fluid-filled oval or round collections encapsulated in a relatively thick wall. They develop 4 weeks after acute pancreatitis and are frequently found on imaging follow-up of pancreatitis. They may be asymptomatic or become large enough to cause mass effects such as gastric outlet obstruction, bowel obstruction, hydronephrosis, and biliary obstruction.

The capsule of a pseudocyst is composed of collagen and granulation tissue, and it is not lined by epithelium. It presents with abdominal pain and epigastric mass. CT is usually done in the evaluation of pancreatic pseudocysts.

Observation is the preferred treatment in cases where the size of the pseudocyst is less than 6 cm and arises from the tail of the pancreas. Interventions are required when it is complicated with infection, large size causing mass effect, diameter increasing in size or greater than 6 cm, recurrence following previous resection.

Treatment includes:

  • Open surgical debridement
  • Cystenterostomy
  • Endoscopic cyst-gastrostomy
  • Percutaneous drainage
  • Octreotide infusion (decreases the amount of pancreatic secretions)

Based on the revised Atlanta classification, peripancreatic fluid, and their collections can be classified into 4 different types based on their morphology and time of presentation:

  • Interstitial edematous pancreatitis (IEP):
    • APFC- acute peripancreatic fluid collection. Non-necrotic fluid collection presenting within 4 weeks 
    • Pancreatic pseudocyst- non-necrotic fluid collection when it undergoes encapsulation (after 4 weeks)
  • Necrotizing pancreatitis:
    • ANC- acute necrotic collection. Necrotic fluid collection presenting within 4 weeks 
    • WON- walled-off necrosis. Necrotic fluid collection when it undergoes encapsulation (after 4 weeks)

Collections that contain non-liquefied material or show the presence of gas, are more likely to be infected.

Note: High levels of CEA is suggestive of mucinous neoplasm.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of chronic pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
Hyperparathyroidism (not hypoparathyroidism) causes chronic pancreatitis as it causes hypercalcemia. 

High alcohol consumption is the most common cause of chronic pancreatitis (60 – 70%).

Gallstone is the most common cause of acute pancreatitis.

Smoking increases the risk of alcohol-induced chronic pancreatitis.

Other causes include:

  • Chronic duct obstruction
  • Autoimmune pancreatitis
  • Tropical pancreatitis
  • Hereditary pancreatitis

Related Pearl: Pancreas - Most Commons

M/C cause of acute pancreatitis: Gallstones

M/C cause of chronic pancreatitis: Alcohol

M/C cause of chronic pancreatitis in children: Cystic fibrosis

M/C cause of pancreatic calcification: Alcohol

M/C congenital variant: Pancreas divisum

M/C site of thrombosis in chronic pancreatitis: Splenic vein 

M/C site of pseudoaneurysm in chronic pancreatitis: Splenic artery 

Related Pearl: Chronic pancreatitis and pancreatic exocrine insufficiency: TIGAR-O classification system

Toxic-metabolic

  • Alcoholic
  • Tobacco smoking
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Chronic renal failure
  • Medications—phenacetin abuse
  • Toxins—organotin compounds (e.g., dibutyltin dichloride, DBTC)

Idiopathic

  • Early onset
  • Late onset
  • Tropical

Genetic

  • Cationic trypsinogen (PRSS1)
  • Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator gene (CFTR)
  • Calcium-sensing receptor (CASR)
  • Chymotrypsin C gene (CTRC)
  • Pancreatic secretory trypsin inhibitor gene (SPINK1)

Autoimmune

  • Type 1 autoimmune chronic pancreatitis
  • IgG4 systemic
  • Type 2 autoimmune chronic pancreatitis

Recurrent and severe acute pancreatitis

  • Postnecrotic (severe acute pancreatitis)
  • Recurrent acute pancreatitis
  • Vascular diseases/ischemia
  • Radiation-induced

Obstructive

  • Pancreas divisum
  • Duct obstruction (e.g., tumor)
  • Periampullary duodenal wall cysts
  • Posttraumatic pancreatic duct scars

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with recurrent episodes of abdominal pain and weight loss.  An X-ray abdomen done shows the following picture. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and X-ray showing the presence of calcification in the pancreas are suggestive of Chronic pancreatitis. 

Chronic pancreatitis is a progressive inflammatory disease in which there is an irreversible destruction of pancreatic tissue. It is more common in males, with a male: female ratio of 4:1.

ERCP is the most sensitive radiologic test for the diagnosis of chronic pancreatitis.

Other tests that can be done are:

  • CECT
  • MRCP- chain of lakes appearance
  • MRI
  • Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS)

Option B: Plain radiograph of the gallbladder may show radiopaque gallstones in only 10% of patients. Rarely, the center of a stone may contain radiolucent gas in a triradiate or biradiate fissure. This gives rise to the ‘Mercedes–Benz’ or ‘seagull’ sign. Ultrasonography (USG) is the most accurate initial imaging modality of choice for the diagnosis of gallbladder stones. They appear as echogenic foci producing acoustic shadows. The image below shows ultrasonography of the gall bladder.

Option C: Sarcoidosis affects the kidneys and sometimes may even end in kidney failure. Symptoms of kidney problems include inflammation, the formation of sarcoid “granulomas” in the kidney, and the formation of kidney stones made of calcium.

Option D: A patient with renal calculi presents with complaints of severe left loin pain and burning micturition. An erect abdominal X-ray showing staghorn calculus is shown below.

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Chronic Pancreatitis

Abdominal pain: most common symptom

  • Site:
    • If infectious foci are in the head of the pancreas, then epigastric and right subcostal pain is common;
    • If the infection is limited to the left side of the pancreas, left subcostal and back pain are seen.
  • Precipitated by food intake, thus weight loss is also seen.
  • Associated with nausea, vomiting

Exocrine insufficiency:

  • Precedes endocrine insufficiency
  • Correlates with morphological changes
  • Manifests with malabsorption symptoms: steatorrhea, diarrhea.
  • Manifests with signs and symptoms of fat-soluble vitamin deficiency, such as bleeding, osteopenia, and osteoporosis: Severe cases

Endocrine insufficiency: Diabetes mellitus

Related Pearl: Chronic pancreatitis and pancreatic exocrine insufficiency: TIGAR-O classification system

Toxic-metabolic

  • Alcoholic
  • Tobacco smoking
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Chronic renal failure
  • Medications—phenacetin abuse
  • Toxins—organotin compounds (e.g., dibutyltin dichloride, DBTC)

Idiopathic

  • Early onset
  • Late onset
  • Tropical

Genetic

  • Cationic trypsinogen (PRSS1)
  • Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator gene (CFTR)
  • Calcium-sensing receptor (CASR)
  • Chymotrypsin C gene (CTRC)
  • Pancreatic secretory trypsin inhibitor gene (SPINK1)

Autoimmune

  • Type 1 autoimmune chronic pancreatitis
  • IgG4 systemic
  • Type 2 autoimmune chronic pancreatitis

Recurrent and severe acute pancreatitis

  • Postnecrotic (severe acute pancreatitis)
  • Recurrent acute pancreatitis
  • Vascular diseases/ischemia
  • Radiation-induced

Obstructive

  • Pancreas divisum
  • Duct obstruction (e.g., tumor)
  • Periampullary duodenal wall cysts
  • Posttraumatic pancreatic duct scars

questions.text: Z plasty is an example of
questions.solution:
• Z plasty is an example of transposition flap
  • It’s a type of random flap
  • The angle at the Z is 60o
  • It gives a lengthening of 1.75 times the original
  • Used in burn scars

questions.text: The given magnetic device is used in the treatment of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The image above depicts LINX, which is the only implantable magnetic sphincter augmentation device (MSAD) used as part of novel gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) therapies.

It is made up of a string of magnetic beads that is wrapped around the distal oesophagus to increase LES resting pressure and thus prevent GER. The propagated food bolus separates the beads during peristaltic swallows, opening the GEJ and allowing the bolus to enter the stomach, after which the beads return to their original position.

Its advantages mainly include:

  • It can be adjusted to fit each patient's oesophagus precisely.
  •  Magnetic forces, as opposed to springs and elastics, are inversely proportional to the distance between them, making it simpler for larger food boluses to pass through.
  • Since magnetic forces don't deteriorate with time, the antireflux benefits shouldn't decrease as the device ages.
  • It can be inserted laparoscopically, avoiding the need for fundoplication.

Another novel therapy for GERD is Esophy X which is a multichannel, flexible endoluminal device that creates an antireflux valve at the GEJ and a full-thickness gastric plication using fasteners.

questions.text: Pulmonary tractotomy is used for
questions.solution:
• Pulmonary tractotomy is a surgical technique in which bleeding from through and through lung injuries is controlled.
  • It involves laying open the tract and individually ligating the bronchi and blood vessels.
  • It is an alternative for lobectomy and has results similar to it.

questions.text: Carneys triad includes all except
questions.solution:
Carneys triad is a rare occurrence of coexistence of 3 tumours namely:

• GIST

• Pulmonary chondroma

• Extra adrenal paraganglioma

questions.text: Identify the instrument given below :
questions.solution:
The above image shows an Allis forceps.

Babcocks forceps:

Collin Duval forceps:

Magill catheter forceps:

questions.text: Bipedicle flap is used in reconstruction of
questions.solution:
Bipedicle flap is a 'bucket-handle' flap supplied from both ends. It is very useful to rebuild the lower eylid.

High yield points:

A bipedicle flap is used for the eyelid whereas a bilobed flap is used for the nose.

questions.text: Name the sign that is being elicited here
questions.solution:
The above image illustrates Chvostek's sign.

Percussion of the facial nerve just below the zygoma causes contraction of the ipsilateral facial muscles (Chvostek' sign), seen in hypocalcemic tetany.

Another sign seen is Trousseau's sign: Carpopedal spasm is induced by occlusion of the arm with a blood pressure cuff for 3 min, raised above the systolic pressure.

High yield points:

  • Troisier sign: Enlargement of the left supraclavicular lymph node.
  • Trousseau sign in GI malignancy: migratory thrombophlebitis, classically described for pancreatic malignancy.

questions.text: All of the following are increased in the metabolic response to surgery and trauma except
questions.solution:
All the hormones increase in response to surgery except:

  • IGF -1
  • Testosterone
  • T3

The integrated response to surgical injury (first 24-48 hours):

questions.text: Urine microscopy is shown below. Identify the type of stone
questions.solution: The above image shows envelope shaped / bipyramidal stones. These are characteristic of Calcium oxalate stones.

questions.text: According to the Forrest classification for peptic ulcer bleed, Grade 3 is _____________

choices.text: Peptic ulcer with non bleeding base

questions.solution:
Peptic ulcer with non bleeding base is classified under Grade 3 of Forrest classification.

  • Forrest classification is used for endoscopic findings and rebleeding risks in peptic ulcer disease. 

Forrest classification for PU bleeding: 

Stage Characteristics Rebleeding
Ia Jet arterial bleeding          90%
Ib Oozing          50%
IIa Visible vessel        25-30%
IIb Adherent clot        10-20%
IIc Black spot in ulcer crater         7-10%
III Clean,nonbleeding ulcer bed         3-5%

questions.text: All of the following are poor prognostic indicators for pancreatitis except:
questions.solution:
Hyperglycemia and not hypoglycemia is associated with poor prognosis.

Ranson prognostic criteria for Gallstone pancreatitis:

At presentation

  • Age > 70 years
  • Blood glucose > 220 mg/dl
  • Lactate dehydrogenase > 400 IU/L
  • Aspartate aminotransferase > 250 IU/L

After 48 hours of admission

  • Hematocrit >10% decrease
  • Serum calcium level <8 mg/dl
  • Base deficit >5 mEq/L
  • Fluid requirement > 4 litres.

questions.text: Most common site of pancreatic adenocarcinoma:
questions.solution:
Ductal adenocarcinomas arise most commonly in the Head of the Pancreas.

Site of Carcinoma Pancreas :

  • Head= 60%
  • Body = 15%
  • Tail= 5%
  • Diffuse involvement= 20%

questions.text: Giant Omphalocele is termed when the defect in anterior abdominal wall is more than:
questions.solution:
Giant omphalocele is the one in  which the abdominal wall defect measures 4 cm or more in diameter.

Omphalocele refers to a congenital defect of the abdominal wall in which the bowel and solid viscera are covered by peritoneum and amniotic membrane.The umbilical cord inserts into the sac.

questions.text: Which of the following gene mutations is not a hereditary risk factor for pancreatic carcinoma?
questions.solution:
The gene mutation not associated with hereditary pancreatic carcinoma is BRCA 1. 

Hereditary risk factors associated with the development of carcinoma pancreas:

Gene Syndrome Increased risk of carcinoma pancreas
PRSS-1 Familial pancreatitis 40% lifetime risk
STK-11 Peutz-Jeghers syndrome >100 fold
CDKN2A Familial atypical mole and multiple melanoma syndromes >40 fold
CTFR Cystic fibrosis 30 fold
BRCA-2 Hereditary breast and ovarian cancer 10 fold
MLH-1 Lynch syndrome 8 fold
APC Familial adenomatous polyposis syndrome 4 fold

questions.text: Which of the following is the second most common affected organ in Hydatid disease, after the liver
questions.solution:
• The lung is the second most common organ affected after the liver.
  • As the parasite (Echinococcus granulosus) can colonize virtually every organ in the body, the condition can be protean in its presentation.

questions.text: All of the following are used to assess severity of acute pancreatitis except:
questions.solution:
• Child Pugh scoring is used to assess chronic liver disease especially cirrhosis.
  • Scales used to assess severity of acute pancreatitis are:
    • Glasgow
    • Ranson
    • APACHE II scoring system

questions.text: Which is the most common radio-lucent renal stone
questions.solution:
Pure uric acid stones are radiolucent.

  • Uric acid stones are hard, smooth and often multiple and multifaceted.

The Mnemonic TIXU for radio-lucent renal stones:

  • Uric acid
  • Xanthine
  • Indinavir
  • Triamterene stones
  • The most common renal stone is calcium oxalate stone.
  • 90% of the renal stones are radio-opaque.
  • Spiral CT is the investigation of choice for renal stones.

questions.text: Most common complication following pancreaticoduodenectomy:
questions.solution:
Delayed gastric emptying is the most common complication of pancreaticoduodenectomy.

Complications include :

  • Delayed gastric emptying - 18% 
  • Pancreas fistula - 12%
  • Wound infection - 7%
  • Intra-abdominal abscess - 6%
  • Cardiac events - 3%
  • Bile leak - 2%
  • Overall reoperation - 3%

questions.text: Most common presenting symptom of Periampullary Tumors of the Pancreas:
questions.solution:
Jaundice is the most common symptom of periampullary carcinoma pancreas followed by weight loss and abdominal pain. 

Symptom Frequency (perecentage)
Jaundice          75%
Weight loss          51%
Abdominal pain          39%
Nausea/vomiting          13%
Pruritis          11%
Fever           3%
GI bleed           1%

questions.text: False statement regarding Mucinous cystic neoplasms:

choices.text: Most common cystic neoplasms of the pancreas
Cyst fluid analysis shows mucin-rich aspirate and high CEA levels
Body and tail of the pancreas is the usual location

questions.solution:
• Mucinous cystic neoplasms is seen in young women, the mean age at presentation is in the fifth decade.
  • High CEA with low amylase is seen in cystic fluid.

questions.text: All are risk factors for acute pancreatitis except:
questions.solution:
Hypercalcemia and not hypocalcemia predispose to acute pancreatitis and the mechanism most likely involves hypersecretion and the formation of calcified stones intra-ductally.

The most common cause of Acute pancreatitis is Gall stones followed by alcohol.

Other causes are:

  • Post-ERCP
  • Abdominal trauma
  • Following biliary, upper gastrointestinal or cardiothoracic surgery
  • Ampullary tumor
  • Drugs (corticosteroids, azathioprine, asparginase, valproic acid, thiazides, oestrogens)
  • Hyperparathyroidism
  • Hypercalcaemia
  • Pancreas divisum

questions.text: Name the incision marked as 8.
questions.solution:
The incision marked as 8 denotes Rutherford Morrison incision.

Rutherford Morrison incision is used for access to sigmoid colon and pelvis in patients where the midline is scarred due to previous surgery.

The different incisions used are:

questions.text: You notice the following appearance in the X-Ray of a patient.  Which of the following conditions is the least likely cause for this?
questions.solution:
The X-ray is characteristic of Pneumoperitoneum which is not seen in Acute intestinal obstruction.

  • The erect X-ray shows gas under both the diaphragms, and the most important cause for this is a hollow viscus perforation.
  • An intestinal obstruction would show multiple dilated loops on X-ray with possible air-fluid levels. Only when the obstruction becomes severe and there is perforation, pneumoperitoneum occurs.
  • Causes other than perforation are:
    • Chilaiditi syndrome (where the intestine is seen between the liver and diaphragm giving a false impression of free air)
    • Sub-phrenic abscess
    • Postoperatively air may be present in the abdomen up to 7 days

Other signs in pneumoperitoneum:

  • Rigler’s sign: The outer and inner walls of the bowel loop are delineated by gas
  • Football sign/ Air dome sign: A central round air collection seen on a supine x-ray
  • Inverted V sign: Gas is seen on either side of the umbilical ligament

Note:

In an emergency setting, where a patient presents with peritonitis and Xray abdomen confirming pneumoperitoneum, an emergency laparotomy is undertaken to manage the bowel perforation.

questions.text: Which of the following has a score of two in modified Alvarado scoring system for acute appendicitis
questions.solution:
Right Iliac fossa Tenderness has a score of 2 in the  Modified Alvarado scoring Acute Appendicitis.

 

           Modified Alvarado scoring Acute Appendicitis
              Symptoms                        Score
  • Right iliac fossa pain
  • Nausea / vomiting
  • Anorexia
  • 1
  • 1
  • 1
                                             Signs
  • Right iliac fossa tenderness
  • Fever
  • Rebound tenderness
  • 2
  • 1
  • 1
                                              Tests
  • WBC> 10000
  • Left shift of neutrophils
  • 2
  • 1

questions.text: The following hemorrhoids in a patient prolapse through the anus on straining but reduces spontaneously. It belongs to which grade?
questions.solution:
Grade 2 hemorrhoids prolapse on straining and reduce spontaneously afterward.

Grading of hemorrhoids:

Grades of internal haemorrhoids           Description
Grade 1 Bleeding only
Grade 2 Bleeding and protrusion, with spontaneous reduction
Grade 3 Bleeding and protrusion that require manual reduction
Grade 4 Bleeding and prolapse that cannot be reduced.

Hemorrhoids are cushions of submucosal tissue containing venules, arterioles, and smooth muscle fibers that are located in the anal canal. They can be classified into external and internal hemorrhoids according to their location.

Image below shows the endoscopic picture and diagrammatic representation of the first-degree hemorrhoids.

 

Image below shows the second-degree hemorrhoids.

 

Image below shows the third-degree hemorrhoids.

 

Image below shows the fourth-degree hemorrhoids.

Related Pearl: Grading of hemorrhoids

GRADE

SYMPTOMS AND SIGNS

First degree

Bleeding; no prolapse

Second degree

Prolapse with spontaneous reduction

Third degree

Prolapse requiring manual reduction

Fourth degree

Prolapsed, cannot be reduced

Related Pearl: Differences between internal and external hemorrhoids

Internal hemorrhoids External hemorrhoids
Located proximal to the dentate line

Located distal to the dentate line
Covered by transitional and columnar epithelium Covered by richly innervated squamous epithelium
Caused by pressure on superior rectal veins Caused by pressure on inferior rectal veins
Painless, can be ligated Painful, not ligated
Banding is preferred Excision is done
